Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Models for Functional Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nonlinear methods for Functional Data Analysis lead to flexible and versatile statistical models, inference and analysis methods for data that include samples of random functions. Such data accrue in the study of time-dynamic phenomena such as electricity consumption curves or biological trajectories and also in a large number of longitudinal studies across the sciences. Methods for functional data analysis have been rapidly evolving over the past few years and are increasingly viewed as essential for the analysis of time-dynamic phenomena. To date, linear models for functional data have been relatively well investigated, both in terms of theoretical and practical aspects, and statistical tools that are based on these methods are available for data analysis. However, the class of linear functional models is quite narrow and often not adequate in practical data analysis. In contrast, relatively little is known about more general and more flexible nonlinear approaches. This research seeks to remedy this situation by developing a class of nonlinear functional methods. The potential value of such models for applications is high, especially in scenarios where one observes repeated functions in time or space, or where one wishes to study regression relations that include functional components as predictors or responses. Nonlinear functional methodology includes representations of samples of trajectories by means of nonlinear components or through mixture models. These approaches are useful for applications where random time warping plays a role, and for the construction of quantiles in functional regression settings. The proposed methodology and associated software provides a sensible balance between increased flexibility and structural constraints.


The investigator and his research group develop new methods aimed at the statistical analysis of repeatedly observed trends and trajectories. Such data are increasingly common due to new sophisticated sensors, measurement systems and the widening recognition that a deep understanding and interpretation of time trends and their patterns is often key to better individual and societal decision making. This new methodology is useful to gain insights into the dynamics of time-dependent processes such as human growth, characteristics of freeway traffic patterns, or the comparison of lifetables across countries and calendar years. The proposed nonlinear approaches to such functional data lead to improved and more compact descriptions and to better predictions of outcomes that are related to observed time trends.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Functional Data Analysis is an up and coming field in modern Statistics where one aims at flexible statistical methodology to analyze data that include trajectories and random functions.  

While linear methods have dominated research in the area of Functional Data Analysis up to now, this project demonstrated that valuable additional information and insights can be gained by deploying advanced nonlinear approaches to functional data, which are more flexible than the linear approaches. However, nonlinear methods pose specific challenges that needed to be overcome in the course of this research, specifically their theory is more involved than that of the more established linear models for functional data. In this project, we developed such theory to underpin the nonlinear methods that we propose. The rewards that flow from this are substantial, as the new nonlinear methods can lead to relevant insights in many areas where time-dynamic phenomena play a critical role. This includes markets and finance, including the housing market, where we found time warping models to provide new insights; engineering, where the degradation of materials as time progresses can also be better assessed with nonlinear warping methods; and density warping which plays a role in aligning events and also in normalization of genomic data. Additionally, function-valued processes are a new type of data for which nonlinear methods are of interest. Such data are increasingly collected in wearable tracking devices such as health monitors, where daily curves of activity or movement patterns are of interest to gauge current health, and this type of data also arises in biodemography and other application areas.

This research has led to a new class of statistical technologies and their theory, which has impact in the study of various data that are collected in science and technology but also in common tracking and monitoring devices. Moreover, the methodology has major impact for the analysis of longitudinal studies, where it leads to more flexible methods for such studies that are ubiquitous in the social and life sciences, where one aims to quantify the time dynamics of social and biological phenomena, as well as diseases. Accordingly, in the course of the project the applicability and importance of the methods was demonstrated with various data, for example the demograqphic development of mortality across many countries as calendar time progresses. Other applications include growth monitoring for children, where we demonstrated that our methods allow to flag children with abnormal growth patterns early in their life. 

In addition to the research outcomes and demonstrations that this methodology facilitates the analysis of emerging types of complex and large data and leads to new insights about the underlying dynamic phenomena that generate these data, the project also involved training and educational components. Several PhD students were trained in general research techniques in Statistics and Functional Data Analysis in particular,  and several tutorials were given for researchers in different areas, in addition to many invited talks at conferences and at universities.
